document.heading: District of Columbia Workers’ Compensation Act of 1979 Amendment Act of 1994

history.narrative: Law 10-169, the “District of Columbia Workers’ Compensation Act of 1979 Amendment Act of 1994,” was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 10-143, which was referred to the Committee on Labor. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on June 21, 1994, and July 5, 1994, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on July 25, 1994, it was assigned Act No. 10-289 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 10-169 became effective on September 22, 1994.

meta.search-text: kwiktag 062 314 625 Original AN ACT D,C, ACT i0-8 Godillcation District ot Columbia Code 9.93 i Supplement) IN THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA FEBRUARY 24, 1993 To amend on an emergency basis, the Rental Housing Act of 1985 to prevent housing providers from evicting tenants when the temperature is predicted to be below freezing within the next 24 bouts. BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be cited as the "Rental Housing Act of 1985 Frigid Temperature Emergency Amendment Act of 1.993 Sec. 2. July 17, 1985 (D.C. Law 6-10; D.C. Code § 45-2551 is amended as follows a) Subsection (k) is amended as follows 1) By striking the phrase "not exceed 25" and inserting the phrase "fall below 32" in its place 2) By inserting the phrase "or 0 degrees centigrade" before the phrase "within the next 24 hours and (3) By adding a new sentence at the end to read as follows This subsection shall also apply to housing owned by the District government b) A new subsection (k-l) is added to read as follows k-l) Notwithstanding any provisions of this section a housing provider can evict a tenant where the tenanCs action or presence causes undue hardship on the health, welfare, and safety of others Section 501 of the Rental Housing Act of 1985, effective Note, Section 45-2551 Sec. 3. This act shall take effect upon its enactment (approval by the Mayor, or in the event of veto by the Mayor, override of the veto by the Council) and shall remain in effect for no longer than 90 days, as provided for emergency acts of the Council of the District of Columbia in section 412(a) of the District of Columbia Self-Government and Enrolled Original Governmental Reorganization Act, approved December 24, 1973 (87 Stat. 788; D.C.
